data.title: Added key binding functionality for any task.
data.body:
Closes #6550.

**Update:** The usage now is to define a command binding per @dbaeumer.  Once a command binding is added to the task, it will be available for making it a keyboard shortcut.

Example task in tasks.json:
```
		{
			"taskName": "Do Something",
                        "suppressTaskName": true,
			"showOutput": "always",
			"commandBinding": {
				"id": "myproject.specialtask",
				"title": "Do something",
                                "category": "Optional category"
			}
		}
```

Then `Do something` will show up in the menu and to add a keyboard shortcut, do this in keybindings.json:
```
  {
    "key": "ctrl+r r",
    "command": "myproject.specialtask"
  }
```

data.title: Theme settings should be stored in user.json

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.4.0 (1.4.0)
- OS Version: OS X/macOS 10.11.6 (15G31)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Set theme
2. Check configuration files

Storing the selected theme in the `storage.json` is a bad idea for several reasons:
- `storage.json` seem to be meant to store temporary and local **state**.
  - The set theme can hardly be seen as neither temporary, not local state.
- Trying to make a sensible backup of settings is confusing, unncessarily hard, and error prone
  - To make a sensible backup, one has to (1) backup `/Users/abc/Library/Application Support/Code/storage.json` for the theme, (2) `$HOME/Library/Application Support/Code/User/*` for the _actual_ preferences, (3) `~/.vscode/*` for extensions. Spreading these out over multiple places is not the moment of least surprise.
  - Trying to make a sensible backup of settings can accidentally leak non-disclosable information. `storage.json` contains many file paths which potentially expose undesired information for the public. There is no easy way to just extract settings from that file that are not "recently used files" or "window locations".

Additionally, `workspaceStorage` should not be in `$HOME/Library/Application Support/Code/User` but rather in `/Users/abc/Library/Application Support/Code`. It follows the same criteria as `/Users/abc/Library/Application Support/Code/storage.json`.

data.title: Can't fold long <style> tag
data.body:
![qunit](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10187203/17784667/f49dbd0a-6585-11e6-9b02-c78aec1633a2.png)
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Win 7 x64

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open HTML file with long `<style>` tag, try to fold it
2. It seems VS Code fails to detect tag's limits and doesn't even suggest fold icons on mouse over

By some reason I can't attach sample HTML file here, but it's simple wrapper for QUnit CSS from https://code.jquery.com/qunit/qunit-2.0.1.css (I directly inserted content of this CSS into the style tag)

In the same time such tag folding works fine in Notepad++

data.title: Changed menu item to Search Feature Requests
Removed UserVoice from README
Change Request Feature to Search Feature Requests in menu
data.body:
As we move from UserVoice we decided on changing the menu item. 

The menu item will change from "Request Feature" to "Search Feature Requests"

This will point to a forward link, which will point to this query https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3Afeature-request+sort%3Areactions-%2B1-desc 

From [vscode-distro product.json](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-distro/blob/master/quality/stable/product.json#L90), this is the forward link that needs to change.

https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=533482

data.title: Clicking string in debugger get stuck with "unexpected identifier" error
data.body:
- VSCode Version: **1.4.0**
- OS Version: Windows 10 pro

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Debug an (in my case nodeJS) app and trigger a breakpoint
2. Click on a string value in Variables > Local, such that you can edit or select it's contents
3. Click away having not made any modification to the variables content
4. Get irritated by the unexpected identifier error that stops you doing anything else ...

[![enter image description here](http://i.stack.imgur.com/oPt1B.gif)](http://i.stack.imgur.com/oPt1B.gif)

data.title: provideSignatureHelp doesn't seem to render anything despite being called and returning data
vscode hangs when inputting some words after opening user settings file from command palette
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4
- OS Version: win 10 & win 7 (both has the same issue)

Steps to Reproduce: 
1. ctrl + shift + p, open command pallete
2. call "Preferences: Open User Settings", then editor will open 2 views, one is default settings, the other is user settings.
3. there are 2 scenes I know to trigger this issue: 
   - <scene 1> keep typing some random words inside user settings json file then the vscode will hangs eventually, and i cannot type or modify any character any more.
   - <scene 2> close all setting files, then open up a new old or new file, then keep typing some random words in it, the vscode will hangs eventually, and i cannot type or modify any character any more.

phenomenon:
1. When editor is hanging, i found that one of editor's process "Code.exe" occupies many CPU resources. If i kill that process, the editor will come back to life, and i can continue to type in characters, though vscode pop out these messages:
2. Error from the extension host: channel closed
3. Extension host terminated unexpectedly. Please reload the window to recover.
4. If i directly open settings.json to editor's view, vscode does not hang.

This issue seems have something with some extension, but i don't know which is. I installed many extensions, it'll be horrible if i enable/disable one by one and test. Is there any fast way to figure out what happed and who blocked the vscode?

data.title: Only update diff editor scroll position when changes have been detected

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 Version 1607

When you are comparing two tabs, and click on another tab and come back, the scroll position is lost and you end up at the top of the file. In my use case, I'm comparing SQL scripts and have an additional tab for manually creating a merge script. When I come back to the compare, I've lost my position.

While it looks like it's refreshing the comparison when you tab back, it seems like it could be a little more intelligent in either remembering the scroll position, or only refreshing if one of the two compared files has been modified.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open two tabs.
2. >Files: Compare active file with...
3. Scroll down on compare
4. Click to another tab
5. Click back to the compare tab
6. Notice that scroll position has been lost.

data.title: Find widget covers results on first line
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Discovered on Ubuntu, suspect it is the same on all

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Turn off word wrap
2. Have a very long first line of file
3. Press Ctrl+f / Open find and replace in top right of window
4. Search for a term that exists in line 1

Observe that the term is hidden by the find-box, the window is not scrolled far enough to the right to show it

E.g. in this image I have searched for "mp3", you can see the start of the path in "Value" but the actual "mp3" itself is hidden because this is the first line in the file.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4096734/17771514/49dff4c2-653b-11e6-85cc-e1806b984d7f.png)

data.title: Add support for background tasks
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4
- OS Version: Windows 10 64-Bit

VC Code tasks are currently blocking. I.e., no other task can be executed until the currently running task has finished. There are situations, though, were it makes sense execute a task while another one is still running. Consider the following example:

I am writing a TeX document using VS Code. I have two tasks. One **build** task that runs pdflatex on my document in order to generate a pdf from my tex file. And a **show** task that opens my pdf in my pdf viewer (SumatraPDF in my case). SumatraPDF supports modifications to the currently shown pdf file while the viewer is still running. I.e., I could change my tex file and run my **build** task. SumatraPDF detects this and updates as soon as the new pdf is finished. However, as the **show** task is running until I close SumatraPDF, I cannot execute the **build** task. Being able to run **show** as a background task that does not block other tasks from being executed would solve this.

I also tried to workaround this by using grunt-exec but I was not able to find a configuration that solves my use case.

Best
Frank

P.S.: Thanks for this great and fast code editor! The more I use it, the more I can imagine that it has the potential to replace a lot of other editors that I am currently using for different tasks.

data.title: Font size for the side panel cannot be changed

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
[Feature request]
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Adjust font size of the code editor
2. See that in the lateral panel (files, search, ...) the code size is not the one specified above

It would be great to at least have consistency with the font size. Right now, while I am searching some variables along all my files, I have almost half of the display busy with the search results because font size is too big and I cannot make it smaller (or at least I haven't found a way to change it).

The code editor panel though is fantastic with the adjusted font size.

data.title: code --help hows wrong help for setting locale?
data.body:
According to @dbaeumer to set a language on startup it is "`code --locale=<lang>`" but the help text proposes "`code --locale <lang>`".

I think our other commands follow the pattern of having the parameter followed with a whitespace so we should maybe be consistent here and change the locale command to take that into account.

I thought we would do the CLI parsing all in one place.

data.title: Is it possible to update/refresh the CodeLens?
data.body:
My plan is to display the results (as done [here](https://i-msdn.sec.s-msft.com/dynimg/IC814850.jpeg) in VS) of unittests against each method. Clicking the code lens would allow one to run (or re-run) that test making it necessary to update the code lens with the latest result.

As far as I can tell this isn't possible.

data.title: Selecting a line also select the first part of the line below it

Steps to Reproduce:

2.  the line is selected plus the cursor on the next line below it
